reviewText: I was ecstatic when this film came out on DVD...I'd first watched it on VCR and was worried that the tape would break.  This is one of my all-time favorite movies.  JoBeth Williams is fantastic in her roles as suburban housewife Cathy Palmer who has a secret dream of being a published author AND as fearless multi-lingual agent Rebecca Ryan.  Her very appearance changes as she leaves one role and enters the other.  This is easily her best performance and I thoroughly enjoyed the snappy writing, the excellent choreography of dance and movement, and the clothes...oh, the clothes.  Tom Conti is a perfect foil and together they rule the screen.  Brava, bravo!
Title: N/A

reviewText: In AMERICAN DREAMER, housewife Cathy Palmer (Williams) wins a trip to Paris by ghostwriting a "Rebecca Ryan" espionage novel. While overseas, she's robbed and then struck by a car. The resulting amnesia leaves her believing she IS this fictional secret agent. Cathy, who'd flown to Paris to meet the author of the Ryan books, battles and defeats (as Ryan) an actual spy (Giannini) with help from the writer's son (Conti). She eventually regains her memory.Also recommended:JoBeth Williams co-stars with Billy Crystal and Alan King inMEMORIES OF ME(1988).Parenthetical number preceding title is a 1 to 10 viewer poll rating found at a film resource website.(6.4) American Dreamer (1984) - JoBeth Williams/Tom Conti/Giancarlo Giannini/Coral Browne/James Staley

reviewText: Cathy Palmer's husband Kevin Palmer (James Staley) is the same type as the husband in "Shirley Valentine" (1989) and "Enchanted April" (1992). You know the kind. Not so much atrophied as just preoccupied with their business and own life that wives like Cathy (JoBeth Williams) become an after thought. However, as her husband says, "The important thing kid is that you are doing something that you like to do." He says this as he nonchalantly brushes her off on his way out the door.Naturally, Cathy's head is full of Rebecca Ryan novels and after winning a Rebecca Ryan writing contest she adds language skills needed for her trip to Europe.This is where the story begins and I stop. I would like to describe more however, let us say that Cathy mysteriously disappears in Europe and Rebecca Ryan suddenly appears with Dimitri to fulfill her mission to save The Count.Move over 007 here come Rebecca Ryan and she always gets her person.Seems Like Old Times
summary: The trick is, never let them enter contests.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Quite simply, this is one of my all-time favorite movies, and I've never understood why the so-called "experts" undervalue it so much.  I think most people can relate to poor JoBeth Williams: trapped in a dead-end life, the only escape through the powers of her own creativity.  The only person Cathy Palmer (Williams) admires is Rebecca Ryan, the outrageous heroine of a series of spy adventure novels.  When Cathy wakes up after being struck by a car, she finds herself at the center of a frenetic Rebecca Ryan mystery.  But is it real?  The plot gets thicker, deeper, and zanier as the film goes along, but never steps over the boundary into absurdity.  Plus, it manages to poke fun at every spy movie cliche to ever come out of Hollywood.  Tom Conti is brilliant as the hapless, unwilling accomplice to Cathy's mad adventure.  A must for romantics and adventurers at heart!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Except for the title and the hideous cover and a brief and totally out of place slapstick kitcken scene, this film is perfect.  It's a sophisticated grown-up version of the young-adult "Romancing the Stone."  The portrayal of the marriage avoids all the Hollywood cliches of bad marriages.  The husband is considerate (on the surface), polite, etc. and totally clueless of his wife's feelings.  So, she has built a dream life for herself made up of romance novels and especially indentifies with one strong heroine, Rebecca Ryan.  In a traffic accident in Paris, she is knocked unconscious and becomes her alter-ego.The genius of the film is that we can see the world through her eyes and also see it the way it is, and the contrast between the two is hilarious.  But the film even goes beyond that.  By chance, some of the people she encounters and treats with suspicion really ARE up to something, and her behavior forces them to make mistakes and reveal themselves.  Thus, illusion and reality begin to merge, with even more hilarious results.  The film's stars, JoBeth, Tom Conti and Giancarlo Giannini, are exquisite in their roles and play off each other splendidly.If you want simple-minded explosions and crude humor, see "Romancing the Stone."  But if you prefer subtlety and layers of meaning, this movie is one of the best ever made.

reviewText: JoBeth Williams is a total character who loses her memory and believes herself to be the character of the book she has written and submitted into a contest to win a trip to Paris.  Her pitiful life as the overworked, doormat wife and mother is left behind as she leads the characters she meets along the way to bring her story to life...and what a story it is!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I'm continually amazed and confounded why the critics butchered this film when it was first released.  AMERICAN DREAMER stars JoBeth Williams in one of her greatest roles, with fine support from Tom Conti and Coral Browne.As a faithful wife to her colourless husband (James Staley) and attentive mother to two boys (Huckleberry Fox, C.B. Barnes), Cathy Palmer finds more romance and adventure in her beloved "Rebecca Ryan" novels.  Cathy enters a contest where she has to submit a story written in the style of "Rebecca Ryan", and wins the trip to romantic Paris.  Her husband forbids her to go, but realising this is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity, Cathy packs her bags and goes alone.  While siteseeing, Cathy is mugged and hit by a car, and waking up the hospital becomes convinced that she is indeed Rebecca Ryan, in the middle of one of her famous cases of international espionage.JoBeth Williams is so wonderful as Cathy/Rebecca and turns in one of her greatest performances.  Not to mention her lush wardrobe of designer clothes!  Tom Conti plays the bewildered author of the "Rebecca Ryan" novels, caught up in Cathy's fantasy.  With Coral Browne and Giancarlo Giannini.  If you have yet to see AMERICAN DREAMER, I highly recommend it.  This is a classic in my book.
summary: JoBeth Williams in her greatest movie performance

reviewText: "American Dreamer" is one of my wife's favorite movies. She's seen it time and again and finally convinced me to sit down and watch it with her. I'm glad she did. It's an oddball sort of silly romp through Paris with JoBeth Williams and Tom Conti that gave me some chuckles and a few laughs. I was reminded of another movie I saw a long time ago called "Romancing the Stone" with Michael Douglas and Kathleen Turner. Anyway, I recommend this movie to anyone who just wants to be entertained for one and one half hours...it's a pleasant way to spend your time.

reviewText: Want some fun, light-hearted entertainment? I can't reccommend this film enough! It  is one of my favorites. I have watched it  numerous times, and I always laugh. There is something about it, that no matter how many times  I view it, it always feels fresh.  Jobeth Williams is beautiful as the  bored house-wife who is patronized, carefully  ridiculed, and ignored by  her boring, self- indulging husband. Everything she attempts to do, he  sabotages by treating her as a misguided child who needs to be under the  control of her husband. When Williams's  Cathy wins a trip to Paris for  two, her husband immediately says it's silly and they won't be going. But  Cathy, who feels it's her one shot at feeling alive, arranges for a  babysitter and heads to Paris in her matronly clothes. Once there, she is  hit by a car, and upon awakening in the hospital, takes on the persona of  Rebecca Ryan, a super-sleuth from a mystery series. Her whole demeaner and  appearance becomes the take-charge character of Rebecca, even to the extent  of charging clothes from elite Paris boutiqes to the hotel where Rebecca  Ryan, mystery book character, resides fictionally.  Rebecca" arrives with all her charged  packages at the famous hotel, greets the baffled " Dimitri," her  assistant (Tom Conti), who is the son of the author of the Rebecca Ryan  books. The adventure quickens, with Dimitri at first thinking it is a joke  arranged by some friends, until the mild but exasperated  "assistant" realizes that Cathy really thinks she's Rebecca Ryan  , who believes she is hot on the trail of a cold war incident. The two  amateurs become enbroiled in real danger, with Rebecca/Cathy at the helm of  the caper.  Jobeth Williams is outrageouly serious in this mad-cap romp  through Paris with the frustrated and mild-mannered Conti at her side.  Together they pull off a side-splitting entanglement of  "fiction," danger, intrique, and romance.

reviewText: Perfect casting and witty writing make AMERICAN DREAMER one of my very favorite romantic comedies.  It almost reminds you of a Blake Edwards '60s comedy with lots of physical comedy, European locations and over-the-top characters.  Williams and Conti are a wonderful combination and the overall picture is played with tremendous heart and commitment.I had the pleasure of telling Ms. Williams that this was one of my favorite films and she enthusiastically thanked me, as it's one of hers, too!If you're even a bit of a romantic, or a dreamer, this is a clever and fun film to rent or own.  Hopefully it will be on DVD in the near future and a commentary by its stars would be a welcome Bonus Feature.

reviewText: An exuberant wife and mother of two, with a flair for the written word finds adventure in "American Dreamer," a comedy from director Rick Rosenthal.  Cathy Palmer (JoBeth Williams) enters a writing contest  (two-thousand words written in the style of the famous "Rebecca Ryan"  adventure-thriller series) and wins a week-long trip for two to Paris,  France, to attend a luncheon to be given in her honor.  When her  patronizing husband, Kevin (James Staley) refuses to go (too much work at  the office), and forbids her to go, as well, she asserts herself, finds a  sitter for her two boys and goes anyway.  While taking in some of the  sights of Paris on her way to the luncheon, she is hit by a car and bashes  her head on the pavement.  When she awakens in the hospital, she thinks she  is Rebecca Ryan, and her real adventures begin in earnest.  First, a new  wardrobe, charged to the hotel in which "Rebecca" resides.  Actually, it's  the home of Alan McMann (Tom Conti), son of Margaret McMann (Coral Browne),  the author of the "Ryan" series.  When Cathy shows up at Alan's as Rebecca,  he takes it as a joke being played on him by one of his friends, and goes  along with it.  And very quickly, he wishes he hadn't; before he knows it,  they're up to their necks in intrigue, involving political machinations and  heads of state from a number of different countries.  Not to worry, though,  "Rebecca Ryan" is on the case.  It's all a flight of fancy, played with  gusto by the delightful JoBeth Williams.  Her Cathy is the dutiful wife and  mother, not necessarily demure, but cautious; when Rebecca takes over,  however, she lets go without restraint.  Rebecca comes on with both  barrels, spunky and full of moxie, and Williams sells it completely,  playing perfectly off of Conti's initially bemused, then confused, and  ultimately alarmed Alan.  Their timing is right on the money, and Rosenthal  never lets it slow down; for this kind of story to work, it has to move  fast, and it has to stay fun, and on both fronts Rosenthal succeeds.  The  story itself may lack some plausibility, but it doesn't make any  difference; just suspend any disbelief for awhile, and go with it, because  this movie is just what it's supposed to be:  Entertaining and funny.  And,  it doesn't hurt that Williams sprinkles it all with charm.  There's some  memorable scenes here, including one in which Rebecca, at a party for some  dignitaries, whispers what turns out to be a secret code to Don Carlos  (Jean Rougerie), an ambassador from Spain, the consequences of which are  hilarious.  The supporting cast includes Giancarlo Giannini (Victor),  Pierre Santini (Inspector Klaus), Leon Zitrone (Ivan), Christopher Daniel  Barnes (Kevin, Jr.) and Huckleberry Fox (Karl).  "American Dreamer" is  light, breezy fare; it's well made and delivered with plenty of fun, thanks  mostly to Williams, with an able and noteworthy assist from both Conti and  Rosenthal.  This may not be a classic, but for an evenings entertainment,  this will aptly fill the bill.  Moreover, it's one you're going to want to  watch more than once, because it's fun, and it's going to leave you with a  smile on your face.  And, when you think about it, that's not a bad bargain  in today's world.

reviewText: I will never understand why this movie did not catch on -- all of the big critics claim miscasting -- but I think this is a delightfully original and very, very funny movie.  With charm to spare, the spy/adventure/dreamer  elements come to together in a creative, if sometime predictable way, and  by the breathless finale, you are completely caught up in the situations of  all of the major players.  JoBeth Williams is so completely committed to  both sides of her character, including of course the novel heroine, that  she shoots sparks and is deliriously entertaining and funny in her  seriousness.  Tom Conti displays his winning puppy-dog quality, and the  oddball pairing seems, in the end, absolutely perfect.  This movie is  addictive: give it a chance; you will not regret it!
Title: N/A

reviewText: It's a shame that this movie is so rarely known. It's actually a gem, perfectly paced and filmed.The hero/heroine with amnesia who develops a new, more dynamic identity, may seem a bit tired these days, but when this movie released it was fresh and strong. Female secret agents were under-utilized and it's nice to see JoBeth Williams - who has natural good looks as opposed to manufactured beauty - be cocky and daring while never loosing her wit. Tom Conti makes an excellent love interest. He's charming and sophisticated yet utterly zany at times.The twists and turns keep the viewer fascinated and the movie has my most favorite false ending of any I have watched on the big screen.American Dreamer remains among my top 10 favorite films of all time.
